metadata.title: A simple model to show the relative risk of viral aerosol infection and the benefit of wearing masks in different settings with implications for

abstract.text: Background . Widespread use of masks in the general population is being used in many countries for Covid-19 . There has been reluctance on the part of the WHO and some governments to recommend this . Methodology . A basic model has been constructed to show the relative risk of aerosol from normal breathing in various situations together with the benefit from use of masks which is multiplicative . Results . Social distancing at 2 metres is validated but in confined areas is time limited and the use of masks in the absence of extremely good ventilation is important. Where social distancing is not possible at all times or an infectious person is in a confined area for a prolonged period there is a higher risk of infection requiring higher grade protection . Conclusions . The use of masks should be factored into models and used at an early stage as widespread use of more efficient masks could have a large impact on control and spread of infection . Public health planning requires stockpiling masks and encouraging everyone to have suitable masks in their household when supplies are normalised . The use of a cloth mask will be better than no protection at all .

body_text.text: Concerning Covid-19 the WHO advice from January 2020 [1] is that masks for the general population are not required except for those with respiratory symptoms. In April this changed to medical masks should be reserved for health care professionals [2] , citing that mask wearing by the public might lead to complacency , however , informing the public that masks are not needed is potentially more damaging . The advice appears to be contradictory to the 2019 document for influenza which states that the approach should be multifaceted including ,'Face masks worn by asymptomatic people are conditionally recommended in severe epidemics or pandemics, to reduce transmission in the community.' , although it does mention the possibility of reduced supply to health professionals and increase in prices as a consequence. [3] Even basic masks can help to prevent droplet spread which the WHO states is the primary spread of Covid-19 together with touching fomites , although aerosol spread is important and not surprising with a relatively high R0 number and findings in SARS and influenza [ 4] . The UK has adopted a similar policy based on having no evidence base that a decision cannot be made . A rapid Cochrane review commissioned by the WHO assessing quarantine alone or with other public health measures to control Covid-19 does not mention masks . [5] A past Cochrane review [ 6] for influenza showed low level evidence in favour of general mask wearing but due to the lack of good quality studies could not make a positive recommendation pointing to compliance issues but these studies do not translate to a pandemic with significant morbidity . A further review by Public Health England concluded that low level evidence suggested there was benefit of masks for health care workers and in the community but community use could not be recommended [7 ] . It seems illogical in a pandemic with significant morbidity that only health care workers need protected when the driving force for their need is the numbers of people from the community being admitted to hospital. Greenhalgh referred to the precautionary principle when there is no evidence for doing something but where the risk of doing nothing could cause considerable harm in relation to recommending the use of masks in the general population [8] and Cowling asked for a rational approach to the use of masks . [ 9] Aerosol spread will be much more in coughing and sneezing , than in speaking or normal breathing , however some individuals produce excessively high amounts of aerosol particles > 10,000 per litre in normal breathing [10 ] which may be one possible mechanism for superspreading . From an observation in influenza [ 11] causing 100% infection in a confined space it was postulated that there must be a relationship between the amount of virus expelled into the air , the ventilation of the area and the time exposed . From this a simple model has been constructed to show the relative benefit of mask wearing in relation to the infectious dose of a virus in aerosol . A Health and Safety review found a 6 times reduction in bioaerosol passing through surgical masks with and estimated 100 times reduction for an FFP3 mask , with much of the inefficiency of surgical masks being due to leakage or poor fit [12] . Cloth masks are acknowledged to give some protection which may only have an improvement factor of 2 . [ 13] Method Infectious dose (ID) is the amount of virus needed to be inhaled to cause infection . Many factors could affect this and the bioavailability of the virus once inhaled together with mucosal defences . A review by Nikitin suggested a figure of 1.9 x 10 3 for influenza [14] . Regarding fine aerosol that can penetrate more deeply into the lungs it is quite possible that a much lower dose is required . For this comparative study an ID at 1000 was used especially as this fitted best with scenario 2 ( Table 2 ) and the original observation . Not all aerosol particles contain virus which may only be 10 % of aerosol but can be more . [15] For this study 30% of particles being infectious was taken at av = 0.3 .

For an infected person breathing out aerosol particles P = 500/litre is used which is the cut off value between a low and high producer of aerosol . [10] Ev is the volume of air expired by the infectious person per minute [tidal volume x breaths/min] for this study taken as normal breathing 500ml x12 breaths per minute = 6 litres /min Bv is the volume of air inspired by a non infected person per minute [tidal volume x breaths/min ] for this study taken as normal breathing 500ml x12 = 6 litres /min F1 is the filtration factor of a mask for an infectious person breathing out , F2 is the filtration factor for non infected person breathing in . For no mask F is 1 , for x 6 reduction is 0.167 , x100 reduction 0.01 . Using this data and that from a study [16 ] on the reduction factor , inspiratory and expiratory at 30 , 50 and 80 l /min extrapolating to 6l/min : cloth mask F1 is 0.75 F2 0.5 , surgical mask F1 is 0.333 F2 is 0.167 , FFP3 F1 is 0.333 F2 0.01 .
Ve is the amount of ventilation given by the percentage of air replaced with fresh air per minute Ve is % /100
At a distance under one metre the volume is not applicable due to risk of directly breathing the same air e.g. one person breathes in as the other breathes out .
Infectious Dose ID = P(av) EvF1 (Bv /Ev) F2 Ve t where t is time in minutes .
( Bv cannot exceed Ev i.e. max for Bv/Ev is 1 )
Considering the exhaled infectious air dispersed into a volume V ( the parameters are given in appendix I ) .
For zero decay constant :
For nonzero :

This is a comparative analysis not an actual situation for any particular virus and estimated values from the literature are used . Any of the chosen parameters could be less than the actual for instance the aerosol may only have 10% infectious particles , ID could be 3000 but equally particles exhaled by an individual could be 10 times more.

Decay of aerosol is complex and will vary for virus , particle size and humidity . Adams et al. found a sharp decay at the start , although reduced by humidity , with recovery over longer periods [17] which may be due to smaller particles surviving longer . Cowling found that 87%% of particles [18] emitted are less than 1 micron . At this size there is less potential space for a virus , for instance an aerosol particle 1 micron in diameter is much more likely to have a maximum of one SARS-CoVid-2 . The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 5, 2020. . particle measuring 0.12 microns in diameter . Yang found in different public places enough influenza virus in the air to cause infection and that a steady state will be reached [19] . Smaller particles can stay airborne for hours in a humid environment with only a 10% loss of infectivity [20] . For this study it was assumed one infectious particle releases only one viral particle and in the calculations the median aerosol half life of 1.2 hours for SARS-CoVid-2 found by van Doremalen was used . [21] The exponential decay constant represents all loss processes which can be combined as:
body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: Processes such as ventilation, loss onto surfaces, decay of the virus and convection/diffusion away from the individuals in large spaces contribute to this value. The model assumes that the particles expired are instantly diluted to give a uniform concentration in the volume. In reality the distribution in space would be complex and so must be regarded as an effective interaction volume rather than the precise volume of any particular region. Additionally, ventilation and convection or diffusion would create a complex spatial and temporal dependence of the concentration so the contribution to by these processes must be considered as an effective value to model the loss of the virus from the system and not a precise value. It does not take account of localised directional air flow which in theory could increase the infectious dose i.e. directing aerosol towards a person .
body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: It is uncertain what the minimum cumulative dose for infection is and over what period i.e. the minimum number of virus particles that non specific defences can cope with per hour or minute . It is assumed the ID is cumulative at least over a relatively short period for this study minutes to a few hours .
body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: The aerosol absorbed by each person inhaling would reduce the amount of infectious particles also increased by use of a mask and this is not factored in this model . As it is divided by the volume which is at least 2000 litres for this study then the effect on the results for the scenarios is very small especially at shorter times.
body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: The model shows for two people wearing masks the protection is multiplicative not additive . Scenario 1 ( table 1) shows a high risk being close to someone breathing normally, potentially only for a short time . Wearing a mask will reduce the number of infectious particles which could mean reducing the chance of infection or even having a milder infection . Combining a surgical mask in the infectious and non infected person gives a 2.8 times improvement from a surgical mask only on the non infected person and a 17 times improvement from no mask at all . The more people wearing higher quality masks will give more improvement and less risk of infection . Scenario 2 ( table 2) with two people on a half hour car journey reaching the ID by the end . There is a greatly reduced infectious dose with a non infected person wearing an FFP3 mask but all the masks reduce the ID . Both wearing a surgical mask is of considerable benefit although not as good as FFP3 . Scenario 3 ( table 3 ) shows that an infectious person in a confined area for 3 hours with little or no ventilation will give a high risk of infection when someone enters and the benefit of FFP3 . As there is only a short time benefit from a surgical mask or cloth mask ventilation with clean air is needed for further improvement . Figure1 shows that a steady state in concentration in a restricted volume occurs quickly with 5% of the air being replaced per minute . Such a situation could be a taxi where the driver is not separated from the passengers , or an infectious person in a cubicle with little ventilation . Scenario 4 ( table 4 ) shows a person in an enclosed area with a larger volume for 3 hours and a non infected person entering . This gives a low risk situation but a cloth mask can give an even larger improvement . Scenario 5 ( table 5 ) shows 2 people socially distanced in a confined area such as a work place . It shows how social distancing can work but it is time limited in a confined area which needs to be extended with masks and ventilation over a longer period . Interestingly the effect of both wearing surgical masks was greater than 200 litres per minute ventilation but both combined made an extremely large difference .

body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: Wearing a mask is beneficial at every aspect of infection modality . It can reduce aerosol inhalation with varying degrees of efficiency , from cloth to FFP3, all masks will reduce large droplets and reducing both will reduce fomite contamination as wide distribution of virus in infected patients' rooms shows that aerosol deposition is important [23] in addition to droplets and direct touch . Any reduction in the ID could be significant by preventing infection or reducing viral load and degree of infection . [24] The more people wearing higher quality masks in the community will result in more benefit . High risk situations can be identified where greater protection is needed especially where a potentially infectious person is in one place for a long period or people are in close contact even for a short time , then use of masks is important . In addition to masks good ventilation and possibly air filtration can be important , such as in clinical or non clinical work places or anywhere social distancing is time limited by a confined area . Input from health and safety and occupational health agencies could be useful in minimising risk in such places . In areas such as public transport where air borne infections have been found [25, 26] , inside shops where social distancing cannot be fully maintained at all times , or anywhere there is not a large amount of fresh air ventilation , better quality protection is needed . The model suggests validation of strategies already in use such as putting a mask on a patient and ventilation of rooms by opening windows .

In a pandemic early intervention is essential with good quality masks as part of a multifaceted approach . Reductions in infections early on will have considerable benefit due to the number of people each infected person infects . Tracht et al produced a model for influenza that showed even with 50% compliance in the population wearing N95 masks , there would be more than a 36% reduction in the number of cases. [27] They found less benefit for surgical masks but may have underestimated the combined efficiency of wearing surgical masks . Reducing the numbers of infected people early on will give contact tracing and isolation a much better chance to work . Those returning from infected areas should use masks immediately together with isolation . Models in pandemics should include aerosol spread and mask use , noting there was no mention of either in the models published by the UK government . [28, 29] If there is an epidemic with rapid spread in a population with high morbidity a warning is sounding that as soon as any spread out with that country occurs plans for implementing the general use of masks should be engaged . Anytime lockdown is likely masks should already be in general use and would be cost effective even if it is only shortened by a week .

The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 5, 2020. . For Covid-19 the lack of resources is all too evident but a lack of resources should not dictate public health policy , public health policy should ensure resources are available when needed . For masks national stock piles are necessary , high grade protection for the care sector and at least surgical masks for the general population . The more people that can use higher grade protection such as N95 especially on public transport and crowded places the better but if there is a national supply of surgical masks there would be a fall back for those unable to tolerate the higher grade masks or unable to procure them . Manufacturers increasing the shelf life from 5 years to 10 years would make this much more feasible . In addition to a national endeavour once supplies are normalised at a domestic level all households should be encouraged through public health information to keep a supply of good quality masks (N95) that can be used for dusty activities and DIY , then replaced when dirty . Alternatively there are reusable masks such as sports masks which are usually available with PM2.5 2.5 micron pollen or dust filters but could be supplied with additional PM1 O.1 micron filters for pandemics . Exhalation valves are designed to reduce moisture and CO2 in theory but it appears with the current design most valves do not work at low levels of breathing [30] which allows a protective effect in exhaling ; masks without exhalation valves still seem preferable . Improving the exhalation filtering and fit further would improve the combined efficacy of wearing masks .
body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: Most of the issues postulated that masks in the community would be detrimental are hand hygiene issues, such as touching the mask with unclean hands , meaning public educational information is needed and similarly advice on fitting could be addressed . Compliance is not an issue when there is national emergency provided the correct information is given and relatively easy to enforce on public transport or at work or in shops . Protection against eye risk is not a case against masks , which is more likely when close to someone from droplets compared to aerosol ( taking the study results and the surface area of the lungs compared to the eyes ) . In this situation a minimum of a basic mask and hand hygiene will help to reduce this risk which also should apply to those preparing food .
body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: The model shows the relative risk of aerosol in various situations together with the benefit from use of masks which is multiplicative . Social distancing at 2 meters is validated but in confined areas is time limited and the use of masks in addition to good ventilation is important. Where social distancing is not possible at all times or an infectious person is in a confined area for a long time there is a high risk of infection requiring protection . The use of masks should be factored into models and used at an early stage as widespread use of more efficient masks could have a large impact on control and spread of infection . Public health planning requires stockpiling of masks and encouraging everyone to have suitable masks in their household when supplies are normalised . The use of a cloth mask is better than no protection at all .
